articles.title: DECEMBER 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines the December 1987 activity schedule, featuring a NASA film night on Apollo 16 and Mercury, a board meeting, and an astronomical observation field expedition to Fremont Peak State Park. It also announces a general meeting in January 1988 with a presentation by Ernie Piini and notes a holiday break.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article details the December 5th General Meeting, which featured NASA films on the Apollo 16 and Mercury missions. It also includes a call for contributions to the Ephemeris newsletter, highlighting a new celestial calendar addition. Furthermore, it reports on a successful SJAA tour of the Space Telescope at Lockheed, where members saw astronaut Bruce McCandless and learned about the telescope's upcoming June 1988 shuttle deployment.

articles.title: OBSERVING AT FREMONT PEAK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak public observatory has seen increased activity and visitors since its Spring opening, leading to a recent unfortunate incident at the October 17th Public Observing Night. Astronomers setting up behind the Ranger's house require prior approval and are expected to assist the public with proper Star Party etiquette. The State Park Service will not tolerate uncivil behavior towards invited guests, and such actions could result in the loss of observing privileges.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is a collection of classified advertisements for astronomical equipment, primarily focusing on used telescopes and accessories for sale. It features various models from brands like Celestron, Meade, and Tinsley, including Newtonian reflectors, Schmidt-Cassegrains, and refractors, along with eyepieces, mounts, and filters. Additionally, there's an advertisement for new optical windows designed for telescopes.

articles.title: BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: This article functions as a bulletin, featuring classifieds for astronomical equipment, including items for sale and a reward for a stolen telescope mirror. It also provides a comprehensive guide to various astronomical observing events scheduled for December 1987, such as asteroid and lunar occultations, major meteor showers (Geminids, Ursids), lunar terminator observations, and transits of Jupiter's moon Io.

articles.title: LUNAR PHASES
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule for the major lunar phases in December, specifically listing the Full Moon, First Quarter, New Moon, and Last Quarter. For each phase, it details the date along with the corresponding rise, transit, and set times.

articles.title: TWILIGHT
articles.summary: This document, titled "TWILIGHT", presents a table outlining the begin and end times of twilight for specific dates in December (12/7, 12/17, 12/27). It provides a schedule indicating the exact times for Monday, Thursday, and Sunday. The data appears to be a practical reference for daily light conditions.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article by Don Machholz highlights December observing opportunities, focusing on the recent discoveries of four new comets: Levey (1987y), Shoemaker-Holt (1987z), Mueller (1987a1), and McNaught (1987b1). It details their discoverers, discovery circumstances (including equipment and location), initial magnitudes, and orbital characteristics. The report also mentions the visibility of other comets and notes the significant contribution of amateur astronomers and individuals like Rob McNaught, who was also involved with Supernova 1987A.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides and observational notes for two comets: Comet McNaught (1987b₁) and Comet Bradfield (1987a). For each comet, it lists celestial coordinates (R.A., DEC), elongation, and magnitude over several dates, along with descriptive notes on their visibility, orbital characteristics, and past brightness. Comet Bradfield is noted for its unexpected brightness and dust tail, while Comet McNaught's highly-inclined orbit is highlighted.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p)
articles.summary: This article provides an observing guide for Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p), detailing its positions, times, and predicted magnitudes from late November through early January. Initially described as a lackluster and faint object in the southern sky, the comet is expected to brighten and become more prominent in the northern evening sky, appearing large and diffuse, and offering a contrast to Comet Bradfield.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: The article discusses the Kreutz Sungrazing Group, a unique category of long-period comets representing less than 2% of all comets. These comets originate from a common source, orbit the sun very closely, and likely derive from one or two fragmented 'supercomets.' While satellite observations have detected them crashing into the sun, their faintness makes them challenging to observe from Earth, and their appearance remains unpredictable for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: This article, "The Celestial Tourist Speaks" by Jay Reynolds Freeman, offers practical advice on inexpensive gadgets and accessories that significantly enhance the amateur astronomer's experience. It details solutions for common observing challenges, such as modifying red flashlights for proper dimness, preserving night vision with an eyepatch, and specialized mittens for cold-weather handling of equipment. The author also recommends multi-purpose tools like Swiss Army knives and Leatherman tools for equipment assembly, fold-up Allen wrench sets, and a simple DIY hook for holding eyeglasses.

articles.title: SHUTTLE RECOVERY EFFORT PROCEEDING
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle recovery effort is proceeding with a successful subscale test of a redesigned solid booster joint, showing no anomalies despite induced flaws. However, a small leak discovered in a main engine heat exchanger will necessitate a replacement, making the June 2, 1988 launch schedule very tight. Additionally, the allowable payload and abort weights for the shuttle have been increased.

articles.title: ROUGH GOING FOR SPACE STATION
articles.summary: NASA has delayed awarding $600 million in space station hardware contracts due to potential federal budget cuts imposed by Gramm-Rudman-Hollings, which could force a 5-12 month postponement of the project. This setback complicates negotiations with international partners, who recently found a draft agreement unacceptable. Despite these challenges, analysts project a 30-year orbital lifetime for the station and have identified a four-person crew structure.

articles.title: TITAN 3 LAUNCHES RESUME
articles.summary: Titan 3 launches have resumed after an 18-month hiatus, with the first launch, a Titan 34D carrying an Air Force payload, occurring on Oct. 26th. Another powerful expendable booster is currently being prepared for launch from Pad 40 at Cape Canaveral.

articles.title: GYROS INSTALLED ON MIR SPACE STATION
articles.summary: Six single-axis gyros have been installed in the Kvant astrophysics module, which is docked to the Mir space station. This installation aims to reduce Mir's reliance on fuel-consuming thrusters, thereby preventing contamination of the space environment near the station, crucial during experiments and observations.

articles.title: NO NEW STARTS FOR NASA IN FY 1989
articles.summary: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has rejected all new project starts for NASA's FY 1989 budget. This decision prevents the initiation of two key planned missions: the Comet Rendezvous Asteroid Flyby (CRAF) and the Advanced X-Ray Astrophysics Facility (AXAF).

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, featuring guest speakers on various astronomical topics and visual presentations. These meetings also include "Indoor Star Parties," informal sessions for members to share interests in areas like astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. The article provides directions to the venue and specifies the meeting times.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Monthly "Indoor Star Parties" are informal gatherings for amateur astronomers to share interests, discuss astronomy, and enjoy company. These events often feature telescope sharing, astrophotography slideshows, and also host Board Meetings and Introductory Astronomy Workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation through field expeditions held on Saturdays closest to the New Moon. These events take place at various designated locations, ranging from sites near San Jose to distant places like Yosemite National Park. Attendees should consult the EPHEMERIS for directions and specific location details.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park serves as a highly popular destination for Bay Area amateur astronomers, offering prime conditions for deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, and hosting the Fremont Peak Observatory's 30-inch public telescope. The article provides detailed directions to the park and highlights the activities of the San Jose Astronomical Association, which publishes the "EPHEMERIS" newsletter and organizes gatherings at the park.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T', and 'Junior' with their respective costs. It requests personal contact information, an optional questionnaire about astronomical interests and areas of expertise, and provides instructions for submission to the treasurer.
